title-group.article-title: Polyneurines A H, iboga alkaloids from Tabernaemontana polyneura

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Polyneurines A H, iboga alkaloids from
Tabernaemontana polyneura

Sin-Yee Tang a , Chun-Hoe Tan b, d , Kae-Shin Sim b , Kien-Thai Yong b , Kuan-Hon Lim c , Yun-Yee Low
a, ** , Siew-Huah Lim
a, *
a Department of Chemistry , Faculty of Science , Universiti Malaya , 50603, Kuala Lumpur , Malaysia
b Institute of Biological Sciences , Faculty of Science , Universiti Malaya , 50603, Kuala Lumpur , Malaysia
c School of Pharmacy , University of Nottingham Malaysia , Jalan Broga , 43500, Semenyih , Selangor , Malaysia
d Department of Biotechnology , Faculty of Applied Science , Lincoln University , 47301, Petaling Jaya , Selangor , Malaysia
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p: Iboga
Alkaloids
ECD
DP4+
X-ray diffraction
A B S T R A C T

Eight undescribed iboga alkaloids, polyneurines A H, were isolated from the bark of
Tabernaemontana polyneura
. The structures of these alkaloids were established by interpretation of the MS and NMR data, while the configurations were determined using GIAO NMR calculations and DP4+probability analysis, TDDFT-ECD method, or X-ray diffraction analysis. Polyneurine A possesses a γ -lactone unit embedded within the iboga skeleton, while polyneurines D and E incorporate a formylmethyl moiety at C-3 of the iboga skeleton. Biosynthetic pathways towards the formation of polyneurines A, C, D, and E were proposed.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
2. Results and discussion
sec.p:
Polyneurine A ( 1 ) was obtained as a light orange oil, [α] D 25 44 ( c 0.2, CHCl 3 ). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima at 226, 284, and 291 nm , indicating the presence of an indole chromophore, while the IR spectrum showed absorption bands at 3427 and 1756 cm 1 , suggesting the presence of NH and γ -lactone functions, respectively. The HRDARTMS data showed an [M + H] + peak at m/z 323.1761 corresponding to the molecular formula C 20 H 22 N 2 O 2 . The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed the presence of an indolic NH ( δ H 9.59), four aromatic resonances ( δ H 7.10–7.49) due to an unsubstituted indole moiety, as well as an ethyl side chain ( δ H 1.03, t, J = 7.5 Hz, Me-18; δ H 1.80, dq, J = 14.5, 7.5 Hz, H-19a; δ H 1.98, dq, J =14.5, 7.5 Hz, H-19 b). The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) showed a total of 20 carbon resonances comprising one methyl, six methylenes, six methines, one ester carbonyl, one tertiary carbon linked to an ester oxygen, two tertiary carbons bonded to indolic nitrogen, and three quaternary carbon atoms. The COSY data revealed the presence of NCH 2 CH 2 , CH 2 CHCH 2 , and CH 2 CH 3 partial structures, corresponding to N–C-5 C-6, C-15 C-14 C-17 and C-19 C-18, respectively ( Fig. 2 ). These structural features are reminiscent of the iboga skeleton, e.g., coronaridine ( 9 ) (
), except for the absence of signals due to H-20 and the ester methyl in 1 . This is in agreement with the molecular formula of 1 , which differs from that of 9 by 16 mass units ( CH 3 +H). In addition, the 13 C NMR data of 1 displayed an upfield shift of the C-16 resonance from ca. δ C 55 in 9 to δ C 45.7 in 1 , whereas the signal of C-20 (usually observed at ca. δ C 40 as in 9 ) was significantly shifted downfield to δ C 88.1, likely due to being linked to an oxygen atom. These observations suggested the presence of a lactone bridge that connects C-16 and C-20 ( Fig. 1 ), which was confirmed by the three-bond correlations observed from H-17 to C OO, as well as from H-14 to C-16 and C- 20 in the HMBC spectrum ( Fig. 2 ). The relative configuration of 1 was deduced to resemble that of coronaridine ( 9 ) based on the NOE data ( Fig. 3 ). The NOEs observed for H-21/H-5 α and H-9/H-6 α suggested that H-5 α , H-6 α , and H-21 occupied the same face, whereas the NOEs observed for H-3b/H-5 β , H-6 β , H-17 β and H-3a/H-15 β indicated that these protons were cofacial. Similarly, H-17 α and H-15 α were assigned based on the NOE observed between H-17 α and H-15 α .
* Corresponding author.
** Corresponding author.
E-mail addresses: yylow@um.edu.my (Y.-Y. Low), shlim80@um.edu.my (S.-H. Lim).

Polyneurine B ( 2 ) was initially isolated as a colorless oil, [α] D 25 44 ( c 0.5, CHCl 3 ), and subsequently as colorless plates from CCl 4 /MeOH (mp 175–177 ο C). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima at 217, 220, 285, and 292 nm , indicating the presence of an indole chromophore, while the IR spectrum showed absorption bands at 3258 and 1716 cm 1 , suggesting the presence of NH/OH and ester carbonyl functions, respectively. The HRESIMS data showed an [M + H] + peak at m/z 373.2139, which corresponds to the molecular formula, C 21 H 28 N 2 O 4 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) of 2 were generally similar to those of 3-hydroxy-3,4- seco coronaridine ( 14 ) (
), suggesting that they share a similar basic skeleton. The 1 H NMR data of 2 showed the presence of an indolic NH ( δ H 8.55), four aromatic hydrogens ( δ H 7.07–7.46) and a methyl ester ( δ H 3.65), while the 13 C NMR data showed a total of 21 resonances, including the notable downfield shift of the C-3 methylene resonance to δ C 67.3 (which was commonly observed at ca. δ C 52 in 9 ), indicating a cleavage of the C-3 N-4 bond and substitution of an OH at C-3. The most pronounced difference in the NMR data between 2 and 14 was the presence of a hydroxyethyl group at C- 20 in 2 , in place of the ethyl side chain in 14 . This is consistent with the observed oxymethine resonance at δ C 72.0 in the 13 C NMR spectrum, as well as the signals due to a hydroxyethyl side chain ( δ H 1.39, d, J = 6.5 Hz, Me-18; δ H 3.86, qd, J = 6.5, 3.0 Hz, H-19) in the 1 H NMR spectrum. Analysis of the COSY data also revealed the presence of a CHCHCH 3 fragment in 2 ( Fig. 2 ), in place of the CHCH 2 CH 3 fragment in 14 , due to C-20 C-19 C-18. Attachment of the hydroxyethyl side chain at C-20 was further supported by the following three-bond correlations in the HMBC spectrum, viz., from H-19 ( δ H 3.86) to C-15 ( δ C 27.7) and C-21 ( δ C 53.1), as well as from H-18 ( δ H 1.39) to C-20 ( δ C 42.3) ( Fig. 2 ). The relative configurations at all the stereogenic centers in 2 , except for C-19, were readily determined via analysis of the NOE data ( Fig. 3 ). Since suitable crystals of 2 were obtained, an X-ray diffraction analysis was carried out, which confirms the structure and the absolute configuration of 2 as (14 R , 16 S , 19 R , 20 S , 21 S ) ( Fig. 6 ).
a Assignments based on COSY, HSQC, and 1D/2D NOESY; ‘m’ refers to multiplets or overlapped signals.
b CDCl, 600 MHz.
3 c CDCl, 400 MHz.

Polyneurine D ( 4 ) was isolated in minute amount as a light yellowish oil, [α] D 25 36 ( c 0.1, CHCl 3 ). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima at 225, 285, and 293 nm , indicating the presence of an indole chromophore, while the IR spectrum showed absorption bands at 3376, 1725 and 1718 cm 1 , suggesting the presence of OH/NH, ester, and aldehyde carbonyl functionalities, respectively. The HRESIMS data showed an [M + H] + peak at m/z 397.2126, corresponding to the molecular formula, C 23 H 28 N 2 O 4 , which is 12 mass units higher than that of 3 . The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) accounted for all 23 carbon resonances, including one methyl, five methylenes, nine methines, one methyl ester, one ester carbonyl, one formyl, two tertiary carbons bonded to indolic NH, and three quaternary carbons. The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed some common features with that of 3 , viz., an indolic NH ( δ H 7.85), an unsubstituted indole ring ( δ H 7.11–7.47), a methyl ester ( δ H 3.73), and a hydroxyethyl side chain ( δ H 1.28, d, J =7.0 Hz, Me-18; δ H 3.89, qd, J = 7.0, 2.8 Hz, H-19). However, unlike 3 , a formylmethyl is attached at C- 3 in 4 in
place of the hydroxymethyl in 3 . This is evident from the presence of the aldehyde signal ( δ H 9.76; δ C 201.4) in 4 , as well as the upfield shifts observed for C-3 ( δ C 53.6 in
4 vs δ C 60.5 in 3 ) and C-24 ( δ C 46.3 in
4 vs δ C 62.0 in 3 ). Furthermore, the COSY data ( Fig. 2 ) revealed an extended spin system NCHCH 2 CHO, corresponding to the N-4 C-3 C-24 CHO partial structure. These observations were also consistent with the HMBC data which showed three-bond correlations from the formyl hydrogen to C-3 and from H-3 to the formyl carbon ( Fig. 2 ). The relative configuration at C-3 was deduced to be R based on the observed NOE interactions for H-24/H-15 β and H-3/H-5 β , H-17 β ( Fig. 3 ). The relative configurations of the remaining stereogenic centers were similar to those in 3 , based on comparison of the NOE as well as chemical shift data. Similar to 3 , the 19 R configuration was assigned based on the chemical shifts of H-18 ( δ H 1.28), H-19 ( δ H 3.89), H-21 ( δ H 4.14), and C-21 resonance ( δ C 55.0) ( vide supra ). In addition, the GIAO NMR calculations and DP4+ analysis supported 4 with 19 R configuration as the correct relative configuration, with 100% DP4+ probability (all data) ( Fig. 7 ). Finally, the absolute configuration of 4 was established as (3 R , 14 R , 16 S , 19 R , 20 S , 21 S ) based on comparison of the experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 4 ).

Polyneurine E ( 5 ) was obtained in minute amount as a light orange oil, [α] D 25 29 ( c 0.1, CHCl 3 ). The UV spectrum of 5 showed typical indole absorption maxima at 227, 286, and 293 nm , while the IR spectrum showed absorption bands due to NH ( 3378 cm 1 ), ester ( 1726 cm 1 ), and aldehyde carbonyl ( 1717 cm 1 ) functions. The HRESIMS ([M +H] + m/z 381.2174) data established the molecular formula of 5 as C 23 H 28 N 2 O 3 , which is 16 mass units less than 4 , suggesting a deoxy derivative of 4 . The 1 H and 13 C NMR data ( Tables 1 and 2 ) of 5 showed similarities with those of 4 , such as the presence of a formyl group ( δ H 9.77; δ C 202.5), an indolic NH ( δ H 7.80), four aromatic hydrogens ( δ H 7.09–7.47), and a methyl ester group ( δ H 3.71; δ C 52.7, 175.4). The only notable difference in the 1 H and 13 C NMR data between 5 and 4 was the replacement of signals due to the hydroxyethyl side chain present in 4 with signals due to an ethyl side chain in 5 . This observation was also consistent with the presence of a fragment, CH 2 CHCH 2 CHCH 2 CH 3 , which corresponds to the C-17 C-14 C-15 C-20 C-19 C-18 partial structure ( Fig. 2 ). Ethyl side chain substitution at C-20 was also indicated from the HMBC data ( Fig. 2 ), which showed the following three-bond correlations, H-18/C-20, H-15/C-19, and H-19/C-21. Examination of the NOE data ( Fig. 3 ) of 5 showed that its relative configuration was similar to those of 3 and 4 . The absolute configuration of 5 was established as (3 R , 14 R , 16 S , 20 S , 21 S ) based on comparison of the experimental and calculated ECD spectra ( Fig. 4 ).
a Assignments based on HSQC and HMBC.
b CDCl, 150 MHz.
3 c CDCl, 100 MHz.
3 d–f Interchangeable.

Polyneurine F ( 6 )
was initially obtained as a light yellowish oil, [α] D 25 43 ( c 0.4, CHCl 3 ), and subsequently as light yellowish block crystals from EtOH (mp 153–154 ◦ C). The UV spectrum showed absorption maxima at 223, 285, and 293 nm , which were characteristic of an indole chromophore, while the IR spectrum showed the presence of NH/OH ( 3331 cm 1 ), ester ( 1732 cm 1 ), and lactam ( 1657 cm 1 ) functions. The HRESIMS data ([M + H] + m/z 369.1817) established the molecular formula of 6 as C 21 H 24 N 2 O 4 . The 13 C NMR data ( Table 2 ) displayed a total of 21 carbon resonances, comprising six methylenes, seven methines, one methyl ester, one ester carbonyl, one amide carbonyl, two tertiary carbons linked to indolic NH, and three quaternary carbons
, in
agreement with the molecular formula. The 1 H NMR data ( Table 1 ) showed the presence of an indolic NH ( δ H 8.12), an unsubstituted indole moiety ( δ H 7.09–7.48), a methyl ester ( δ H 3.72), and a 1-hydroxyethyl side chain ( δ H 3.74, 3.81, H-18; δ H 1.64, 1.77, H-19). The 13 C NMR data showed the presence of an oxymethylene at δ C 60.2 and a methylene at δ C 37.5, which were attributed to C-18 and C-19, respectively from the HSQC and COSY data ( Fig. 2 ). The COSY data indicated the presence of a CH 2 CHCH 2 CHCH 2 CH 2 partial structure, which corresponds to C-17 C-14 C-15 C-20 C-19 C- 18 in 6 . This was further confirmed by the three-bond correlations from H-18 ( δ H 3.74 and 3.81) to C-20 ( δ C 30.6), and from H-20 ( δ H 2.05) to C-18 ( δ C 60.2) ( Fig. 2 ). In addition, the presence of an amide carbonyl at C-3 was in agreement with the three-bond correlations observed from H-5, H-15, H-17, and H-21 to C-3 ( δ C 176.3) ( Fig. 2 ). Additionally, the presence of the C-3 carbonyl has resulted in a noticeable anisotropic deshielding of H-5 β ( δ H 4.48) (
., 2016 a),
compared to δ H 3.1–3.4 for H-5 β in
1
,
3–5
. The NOE data ( Fig. 3 ) also showed that the relative configuration of 6 was similar to that of compounds 1–5 . Since suitable crystals were obtained, an X-ray diffraction analysis was also carried out which confirmed the structure and provided the absolute configuration of 6 (14 R , 16 S , 20 R , 21 S ) ( Fig. 9 ).

Compounds 1 , 2 , 6 , 7 , and 8 were tested for their cytotoxic effect against several human cancer cell lines (HT-29, HCT 116, MCF7, MDA-MB-231, A549, and PC-3) but were found to be inactive (IC 50 > 10 μM).

sec.title: 3. Conclusions
4. Experimental
sec.p: 4.1. General experimental procedures

Melting points were determined on an Electrothermal IA9100 digital melting point apparatus and are uncorrected. Optical rotations were measured on a JASCO P-1020 automatic digital polarimeter. UV spectra were obtained on a Shimadzu UV-2600 spectrophotometer. IR spectra were recorded on a PerkinElmer RX1 FT-IR spectrophotometer or Spectrum 400 FT-IR/FT-FIR spectrophotometer. HRDART-MS was recorded on a JEOL Accu TOF-DART mass spectrometer, and HRESIMS were obtained on an Agilent LC HR QTOF System Model G6530A or Agilent Technologies 6550 iFunnel Q-TOF LC/MS. 1D and 2D NMR spectra were recorded in CDCl 3 using tetramethylsilane as internal standard on JEOL JNM (ECA 400 MHz) or Bruker Avance III (600 MHz) spectrometers and using a 1.7 mm microprobe for compound 5 . ECD spectra were obtained using JASCO J-810 or JASCO J-815 circular dichroism spectrometers.

sec.title: 4.2. Plant material
sec.p:
Bark of
Tabernaemontana polyneura (King & Gamble) D.J.Middleton (Apocynaceae)
was collected in
June 2016
from Fraser’ s Hill , Pahang , Malaysia (
3.7249 ◦ N
,
101.7143 ◦ E
), and was identified by Dr. K. T. Yong (Institute of Biological Sciences, Universiti Malaya, Malaysia). A voucher specimen ( KLU49438 ) was deposited at the Herbarium, Universiti Malaya
.

sec.title: 4.3. Extraction and isolation
sec.p: Extraction of alkaloids from the ground bark material ( 11.9 kg ) was carried out exhaustively with MeOH at room temperature to afford a viscous extract which was then acidified with 3% tartaric acid. Removal of non-alkaloidal material followed by basification with sodium carbonate and extraction with chloroform gave the crude alkaloidal mixture ( 60 g ). The crude mixture was fractionated by column chromatography (SiO 2 , hexanes/ CH 2 Cl 2 ; MeOH/ CH 2 Cl 2 ) to furnish eleven main fractions (F1–F11). Fraction F2 was rechromatographed (SiO 2 , petroleum ether/EtOAc; MeOH/EtOAc) to give six subfractions (F2a F2f). Repeated purification of the subfraction F2c using preparative radial chromatography (Chromatotron) on SiO 2 yielded compound 1 . Rechromatography of fraction F3 over SiO 2 (petroleum ether/CHCl 3 ; MeOH/CHCl 3 ) gave seven subfractions (F3a F 3g ). Compounds 5 and 8 were obtained from the subfractions F3b and F3c, respectively, by repeated preparative radial chromatography. Further fractionation of fraction F5 by column chromatography (SiO 2 , petroleum ether/EtOAc; MeOH/EtOAc) yielded ten subfractions (F5a F5j). Subfraction F 5g was further purified by repeated preparative radial chromatography to furnish compound 4 . Column chromatography of F6 (SiO 2 , petroleum ether/EtOAc; MeOH/EtOAc) gave 10 subfractions (F6a F6j). Compounds 6 and 7 were isolated from the subfractions F 6g and F6f, respectively, by repeated preparative radial chromatography over SiO 2 . Gel permeation chromatography (Sephadex LH-20, MeOH) of fraction 7 yielded ten subfractions (F7a F7j). The combined subfraction F7c e was subjected to repetitive preparative radial chromatography to yield compound 2 and 3 . The solvent systems used for preparative radial chromatography were MeOH/Et 2 O, petroleum ether/Et 2 O, MeOH/ CHCl 3 , petroleum ether/CHCl 3 , MeOH/ CH 2 Cl 2 , petroleum ether/ CH 2 Cl 2 , CH 2 Cl 2 , MeOH/EtOAc, and petroleum ether/EtOAc. All solvent systems used for preparative radial chromatography were NH 3 -saturated. The yields (mg kg 1 ) of the alkaloids from the bark were as follows: 1 (0.37), 2 (0.59), 3 (0.31), 4 (0.14), 5 (0.13), 6 (0.59), 7 (0.77), and 8 (0.20).

sec.title: 4.4.1. Polyneurine A (1)
sec.p: Light orange oil; [α] D 25 44 ( c 0.2, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH), λ max (Δε) 220 (6.18), 233 (+1.66), 245 (3.27), 288 (+0.83) nm; UV (EtOH) λ max (log ε ) 226 (3.93), 284 (3.31), 291 (3.31) nm; IR (dry film) ν max 3427, 1756 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRDARTMS m/z 323.1761 [M + H] + (calcd for C 20 H 22 N 2 O 2 + H, 323.1760).

sec.title: 4.4.2. Polyneurine B (2)
sec.p: Colorless oil and subsequently colorless plates (CCl 4 /MeOH); mp 175–177 ο C; [α] D 25 44 ( c 0.5, CHCl 3 ); UV (EtOH) λ max (log ε ) 217 (4.15), 220 (4.14), 285 (3.66), 292 (3.61) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 3258, 1716 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 373.2139 [M + H] + (calcd for C 21 H 28 N 2 O 4 + H, 373.2122).

sec.title: 4.4.3. Polyneurine C (3)
sec.p: Light yellowish oil; [α] D 25 28 ( c 0.2, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH), λ max (Δε) 205 (+2.95), 225 (1.33), 244 (+1.26), 275 (0.73) nm; UV (EtOH) λ max (log ε ) 223 (4.22), 286 (3.76) nm; IR (ATR) ν max 3374, 1726 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 385.2130 [M + H] + (calcd for C 22 H 28 N 2 O 4 + H, 385.2122).

sec.title: 4.4.4. Polyneurine D (4)
sec.p: Light yellowish oil; [α] D 25 36 ( c 0.1, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH), λ max (Δε) 206 (+0.33), 214 (+10.49), 230 (4.89), 246 (+17.61), 280 (31.27) nm; UV (EtOH) λ max (log ε ) 225 (4.10), 285 (3.50), 293 (3.47) nm; IR (dry film) ν max 3376, 1725, 1718 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 397.2126 [M +H] + (calcd for C 23 H 28 N 2 O 4 +H, 397.2122).

sec.title: 4.4.5. Polyneurine E (5)
sec.p: Light orange oil; [α] D 25 29 ( c 0.1, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH), λ max (Δε) 203 (+5.56), 221 (1.06), 246 (+5.03), 279 (7.62), 315 (+0.62) nm; UV (EtOH) λ max (log ε ) 227 (4.18), 286 (3.66), 293 (3.63) nm; IR (dry film) ν max 3378, 1726, 1717 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 381.2174 [M + H] + (calcd for C 23 H 28 N 2 O 3 + H, 381.2173).

sec.title: 4.4.6. Polyneurine F (6)
sec.p: Light yellowish oil and subsequently light yellowish block crystals (EtOH); mp 153–154 ο C; [α] D 25 43 ( c 0.4, CHCl 3 ); UV (EtOH) λ max (log ε ) 223 (4.13), 285 (3.61), 293 (3.58) nm; IR (dry film) ν max 3331, 1732, 1657 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 369.1817 [M +H] + (calcd for C 21 H 24 N 2 O 4 + H, 369.1809).

sec.title: 4.4.7. Polyneurine G (7)
sec.p: Orange oil; [α] D 25 25 ( c 0.4, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH), λ max (Δε) 203 (+7.32), 221 (+0.72), 243 (+4.84), 281 (5.92) nm; UV (EtOH) λ max (log ε ) 225 (4.69), 285 (4.11), 293 (4.07) nm; IR (dry film) ν max 3376, 1728 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 371.1984 [M + H] + (calcd for C 21 H 26 N 2 O 4 + H, 371.1965).

sec.title: 4.4.8. Polyneurine H (8)
sec.p: Yellowish oil; [α] D 25 30 ( c 0.1, CHCl 3 ); ECD (MeOH), λ max (Δε) 207 (8.68), 257 (+11.07), 293 (3.63) nm; UV (EtOH) λ max (log ε ) 223 (3.52), 232 sh (3.26), 266 (2.91), 292 (2.84) nm; IR (dry film) ν max 3301, 1732 cm 1 ; 1 H and 13 C NMR data, see Tables 1 and 2 ; HRESIMS m/z 371.1962 [M + H] + (calcd for C 21 H 26 N 2 O 4 + H, 371.1965).

sec.title: 4.4.9. Computational methods
4.4.10. X-ray crystallographic analysis of polyneurines B (2) and F (6)
sec.p: X-ray diffraction analyses were carried out on a Rigaku Oxford (formerly Agilent Technologies) SuperNova Dual diffractometer with Mo K α ( λ = 0.71073 Å) or Cu K α ( λ = 1.54184 Å) radiation at room temperature. Using Olex2, the structures were solved with SHELXT-2018/2 structure solution program using Intrinsic Phasing and refined with SHELXL-2018/3 refinement package using Least Square minimization. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically, and all hydrogen atoms were placed in idealized positions and refined as riding atoms with the relative isotropic parameters. Crystallographic data for 2 and 6 had been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Centre. Copies of the data can be obtained, free of charge, on application to the Director, CCDC, 12 Union Road, Cambridge CB2 1EZ, UK (fax: +44 (0)1223–336033, or e-mail: deposit@ccdc.cam.ac.uk).

Crystallographic Data of 2 . Colorless plates (CCl 4 /MeOH), mp 175–177 ◦ C, C 21 H 28 N 2 O 4 .CCl 4 , M r = 526.26, monoclinic, space group P 21 , a =9.7036 (3) Å, b =9.7698 (3) Å, c =13.5325 (5) Å, β =100.585 (3) ◦ , V =1261.08 (7) Å 3 , Z =2, D calcd = 1.386 g cm 3 , crystal size 0.5 × 0.4 × 0.01 mm 3 , F (000) =548, Mo K α radiation ( λ = 0.71073 Å), T = 293 (2) K. The final R 1 value is 0.0930 (w R 2 = 0.2790) for 6472 reflections [
I > 2 σ(I) ], while the Flack, Hooft, and Parson’ s parameters were x = 0.02 (3), y = 0.05 (2), and z =0.01 (3), respectively. For the inverted structure, the R 1 value is 0.0932 (w R 2 = 0.2796) for 6472 reflections [
I > 2 σ(I) ], while the Flack, Hooft, and Parson’ s parameters were x = 0.98 (3), y = 0.95 (2), and z = 0.99 (3), respectively, from which it follows that the correct enantiomer is the one depicted in Fig. 6 (14 R , 16 S , 19 R , 20 S , 21 S ). CCDC number 2169029.

Crystallographic Data of 6 . Light yellowish block crystals (EtOH), mp 153–154 ◦ C, C 21 H 24 N 2 O 4 .H 2 O, M r =386.44, triclinic, space group P 1, a =7.8152 (6) Å, b =9.4777 (9) Å, c =13.9307 (12) Å, α =77.234 (7) ◦ , β =79.526 (7) ◦ , γ =89.595 (7) ◦ , V =988.98 (15) Å 3 , Z =2, D calcd = 1.298 g cm 3 , crystal size 0.2 × 0.1 × 0.03 mm 3 , F (000) =412, Cu K α radiation ( λ =1.54184 Å), T =293 (2) K. The final R 1 value is 0.0507 (w R 2 = 0.1071) for 7405 reflections [
I > 2 σ(I) ], while the Flack, Hooft, and Parson’ s parameters were x = 0.09 (19), y = 0.10 (18), and z = 0.1 (2), respectively. For the inverted structure, the R 1 value is 0.0508 (w R 2 = 0.1070) for 7405 reflections [
I > 2 σ(I) ], while the Flack, Hooft, and Parson’ s parameters were x =1.08 (19), y =1.10 (18), and z =1.1 (2), respectively, from which it follows that the correct enantiomer is the one depicted in Fig. 9 (14 R , 16 S , 20 R , 21 S ). CCDC number 2169030.

sec.title: 4.5. Cytotoxicity assays
sec.p:
Cytotoxicity assays were carried out following the published procedures (
).

Data will be made available on request.
